item.title: Russia orders Google, Facebook and Twitter to comply with local storage and censorship laws
item.dc:creator: David Meyer
item.description:
The U.S. firms have reportedly been told they must store Russians' local data and metadata on Russian soil, and abide by the same restrictions on free speech to which traditional Russian media must adhere. If they don't play ball, they may be blocked in the country.

Russia orders Google, Facebook and Twitter to comply with local storage and censorship laws originally published by Gigaom, © copyright 2014.

Continue reading…

item.title: Ello investor, co-founder: Funding or not, we hate ads and we want to “shift values”
item.dc:creator: Carmel DeAmicis
item.description:
How will the popular new social network maintain its ad-free philosophy if it’s pressured to bring in venture level returns?

Ello investor, co-founder: Funding or not, we hate ads and we want to “shift values” originally published by Gigaom, © copyright 2014.

Continue reading…

item.title: Apple quickly releases iOS 8.0.2 to fix iPhone issues caused by the prior update
item.dc:creator: Kevin C. Tofel
item.description:
It took just over a day for Apple to fix the iOS software update that disabled both cellular service and the Touch ID on iPhones. The software works as advertised but Apple will have to battle the fact that it let users down.

Apple quickly releases iOS 8.0.2 to fix iPhone issues caused by the prior update originally published by Gigaom, © copyright 2014.

Continue reading…

item.title: Mobile ISP Karma plans a move into home broadband
item.dc:creator: Kevin Fitchard
item.description:
Karma's pocketable mobile hotspot is already used by 100,000 people looking for connectivity on the go. But Karma wants its mobile broadband service to become its customer's primary source of internet access.

Mobile ISP Karma plans a move into home broadband originally published by Gigaom, © copyright 2014.

Continue reading…

media:content.media:title: Karma's LTE hotspot is pocket-sized and easily portable, but Karma may well have a more powerful router planned for your home (source: Karma)
Micha Benoliel Open Garden Sascha Meinrath New America Foundation's Open Technology Institute Steven van Wel Karma Mobilize 2013

item.title: A startup wants to reinvent big data, by ditching binary and putting computers in space
item.dc:creator: Derrick Harris
item.description:
A new startup wants to speed up the process of analyzing data, and the costs of storing it, by housing it in satellites. The idea is out there, but its founder says some of the big pieces to pull it off are already coming into place.

A startup wants to reinvent big data, by ditching binary and putting computers in space originally published by Gigaom, © copyright 2014.

Continue reading…

item.title: Sponsored post: A view on the future of medicine in 2064
item.dc:creator: Gigaom
item.description:
Health care over the next 50 years will leverage the Internet to focus on wellness and prevention. Technology will move our society away from a model of “sick care” to one where individuals can constantly monitor their condition in order to stay healthy.

Sponsored post: A view on the future of medicine in 2064 originally published by Gigaom, © copyright 2014.

Continue reading…

item.title: A flipless Flipboard finally arrives on Windows Phones (as a placeholder)
item.dc:creator: Kevin C. Tofel
item.description:
Has it really been more than a year since Microsoft and Nokia said Flipboard would arrive on Windows Phone? Yes, it has: During the July 2013 Lumia 1020 launch event, it was said the Flipboard will “soon be available.” I guess “soon” is now because Flipboard is out […]

A flipless Flipboard finally arrives on Windows Phones (as a placeholder) originally published by Gigaom, © copyright 2014.

Continue reading…

item.title: Samsung’s unusual Galaxy Note Edge may not be widely available
item.dc:creator: Kif Leswing
item.description:
According to comments made by the Samsung Electronics president, the company sees the Galaxy Note Edge as a limited-edition device. This means a United States launch could be months away, if it ever happens.

Samsung’s unusual Galaxy Note Edge may not be widely available originally published by Gigaom, © copyright 2014.

Continue reading…

item.title: Amazon confirms that EC2 reboots are due to Xen issues
item.dc:creator: Barb Darrow
item.description:
About 10 percent of Amazon's EC2 instances will need to be rebooted starting Friday, according to an AWS update.

Amazon confirms that EC2 reboots are due to Xen issues originally published by Gigaom, © copyright 2014.

Continue reading…

item.title: So that Surface Mini was real after all; maybe it’s not quite dead yet
item.dc:creator: Kevin C. Tofel
item.description:
The Surface Mini is alive according to Brad Sams who says he used one. Thanks to the digital pen and OneNote, Sams thinks Surface Mini was a viable product. Perhaps recent changes to Windows Phone will give the device another lease on life.

So that Surface Mini was real after all; maybe it’s not quite dead yet originally published by Gigaom, © copyright 2014.

Continue reading…

item.title: Apple: Only nine people have reported a bent iPhone 6 Plus
item.dc:creator: Kif Leswing
item.description:
According to Apple, the warped or bent iPhones that some users have reported is "extremely rare" and it doesn't usually happen during everyday use.

Apple: Only nine people have reported a bent iPhone 6 Plus originally published by Gigaom, © copyright 2014.

Continue reading…

item.title: Twitter CEO Dick Costolo calls out the President of Iran; on Twitter, of course
item.dc:creator: Carmel DeAmicis
item.description:
Twitter CEO Dick Costolo took Iranian President Hassan Rouhani to task today for blocking Twitter in his country.

Twitter CEO Dick Costolo calls out the President of Iran; on Twitter, of course originally published by Gigaom, © copyright 2014.

Continue reading…

item.title: Selfie time-lapse videos are now a “thing” thanks to Instagram
item.dc:creator: Carmel DeAmicis
item.description:
Citizens prepare: The selfielapse has arrived.

Selfie time-lapse videos are now a “thing” thanks to Instagram originally published by Gigaom, © copyright 2014.

media:content.media:title: Hyperlapse's popularity ranking since it launched, as measured via downloads by App Annie

item.title: Binge alert: Subscribers now watch more than 90 minutes of Netflix every single day
item.dc:creator: Janko Roettgers
item.description:
Just one more episode: All of your binge watching is adding up, to an average of 93 minutes of Netflix viewing per day, and around 45 GB of data every month.

Binge alert: Subscribers now watch more than 90 minutes of Netflix every single day originally published by Gigaom, © copyright 2014.

Continue reading…

item.title: The new Moto X will go on sale for Verizon subscribers tomorrow
item.dc:creator: Kif Leswing
item.description:
Motorola’s newest high-end phone will be available on Verizon, not that it was ever in doubt. The carrier announced Thursday that the new Moto X will cost $99 for the 16GB model on a two-year contract, or either $499 or $549 at full price, starting September 26. Your […]

The new Moto X will go on sale for Verizon subscribers tomorrow originally published by Gigaom, © copyright 2014.

Continue reading…

item.title: AlchemyAPI now recognizes famous faces (and can learn yours, too)
item.dc:creator: Derrick Harris
item.description:
AlchemyAPI's deep-learning-based system can now be used to tag famous people in photos, or to recognize non-celebrities via labeled images in corporate or social networks. It's the latest -- but not the last -- service the company has released since getting started analyzing text in 2012.

AlchemyAPI now recognizes famous faces (and can learn yours, too) originally published by Gigaom, © copyright 2014.

Continue reading…

item.title: One secret to the success of Quartz, BuzzFeed and Gawker: They look at news as a service
item.dc:creator: Mathew Ingram
item.description:
Most traditional media outlets are used to thinking of journalism or news as something they create and then distribute to a waiting audience -- but seeing it as a product or service instead can change the way you think about your job in some fundamental ways

One secret to the success of Quartz, BuzzFeed and Gawker: They look at news as a service originally published by Gigaom, © copyright 2014.

Continue reading…

item.title: Acquia names software vet Chris Stone to lead its product business
item.dc:creator: Barb Darrow
item.description:
Chris Stone, formerly of Novell and the Object Management Group, is back in the software game, to help drive commercial Drupal products into the enterprise.

Acquia names software vet Chris Stone to lead its product business originally published by Gigaom, © copyright 2014.

Continue reading…

item.title: Sponsored post: Announcing AppDynamics AppSphere 2014 Conference in Las Vegas
item.dc:creator: Gigaom
item.description:
AppSphere 2014 is AppDynamics' technology and business conference. Come to explore forth-coming industry trends that effect Developers, Ops, and Executives. Gain insights from thought-leaders from companies like Amazon, IBM, Google, Citrix, and Microsoft as they discuss best practices for application management and business performance optimization.

Sponsored post: Announcing AppDynamics AppSphere 2014 Conference in Las Vegas originally published by Gigaom, © copyright 2014.

Continue reading…

item.title: This Android app converts other Android apps to run on Chrome
item.dc:creator: Kevin C. Tofel
item.description:
Converting Android apps to run on Chrome isn't difficult but it can be cumbersome and does require a computer. Now, a new Android app takes care of the process for you so you can run other Android apps on Chromebooks or computers with Chrome.

This Android app converts other Android apps to run on Chrome originally published by Gigaom, © copyright 2014.

Continue reading…

item.title: IBM SoftLayer woos startups running Amazon Web Services, Rackspace
item.dc:creator: Barb Darrow
item.description:
IBM SoftLayer's hybrid bare-metal/cloud infrastructure and free internal networking wins some converts, but it still has a long way to go in the AWS-obsessed world of startups.

IBM SoftLayer woos startups running Amazon Web Services, Rackspace originally published by Gigaom, © copyright 2014.

Continue reading…

item.title: Big data startup Continuuity becomes Cask and is now completely open source
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Vanian
item.description:
Users of Cask's open-source big data PaaS will have three options: CDAP Free, CDAP Standard and CDAP Enterprise.

Big data startup Continuuity becomes Cask and is now completely open source originally published by Gigaom, © copyright 2014.

Continue reading…

media:content.media:title: Jonathan Gray Continuuity Derrick Harris Structure Data 2013

item.title: How we built it: Listen to your customers, especially when they stop talking
item.dc:creator: Peter Hoddie, Marvell
item.description:
This is the second post in our How We Built it package featuring lessons from hardware entrepreneurs on getting from an idea to a product. Marvell offers a lesson in listening to your customer.

How we built it: Listen to your customers, especially when they stop talking originally published by Gigaom, © copyright 2014.

media:content.media:title: An early Kinoma Create without a touch screen.
The current Create with launch software.

item.title: Insteon integrates with Microsoft Cortana for voice control in the home
item.dc:creator: Stacey Higginbotham
item.description:
"Insteon, I'm home!" With those words, an Insteon home automation system and a Microsoft Windows Phone 8.1 handset, you could unlock your doors and turn on your lights.

Insteon integrates with Microsoft Cortana for voice control in the home originally published by Gigaom, © copyright 2014.

Continue reading…

item.title: Studios can now film with drones after reported FAA approval
item.dc:creator: Jeff John Roberts
item.description:
The movie and TV industry will finally be able to fly drones on set, but the FAA has imposed conditions that may make doing so more trouble than it's worth.

Studios can now film with drones after reported FAA approval originally published by Gigaom, © copyright 2014.

Continue reading…

item.title: Motorola Shamu sighting: Nexus 6 tipped with 5.92-inch screen
item.dc:creator: Kevin C. Tofel
item.description:
We're getting closer to what should be a new Nexus phone launch to coincide with the debut of Android L software. Will the next Nexus really have a screen nearing 6-inches in size?

Motorola Shamu sighting: Nexus 6 tipped with 5.92-inch screen originally published by Gigaom, © copyright 2014.

Continue reading…

item.title: iPhone 6, 6 Plus pre-orders: AT&T ruled, while T-Mobile accounted for 5x more than Sprint
item.dc:creator: Kevin C. Tofel
item.description:
Based on data from tracking iPhone 6 and 6 Plus pre-order shipments, Slice says AT&T accounted for nearly half of the pre-orders for Apple's new phones. One in five paid full price for a T-Mobile edition as Sprint-compatible iPhones lagged behind.

iPhone 6, 6 Plus pre-orders: AT&T ruled, while T-Mobile accounted for 5x more than Sprint originally published by Gigaom, © copyright 2014.

Continue reading…

media:content.media:title: Apple's iPhone 6. Photo by Tom Krazit/Gigaom

item.title: Sponsored post: 3 questions raised by the Internet of Things
item.dc:creator: Gigaom
item.description:
For several years now, a connectivity revolution has been slowly brewing all around us; everyday objects like recycling bins, dishwashers, and smoke alarms are going online one by one, adding to the fabric of the Internet that connects us all.

Sponsored post: 3 questions raised by the Internet of Things originally published by Gigaom, © copyright 2014.

Continue reading…

item.title: As Oracle’s OpenWorld approaches and deck chairs shuffle, has Oracle finally figured out the cloud?
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Vanian
item.description:
Oracle's annual conference will be the first without Larry Ellison as CEO; it's going to be fascinating to watch whether or not Oracle's cloud announcements will make an impact in an already crowded cloud world.

As Oracle’s OpenWorld approaches and deck chairs shuffle, has Oracle finally figured out the cloud? originally published by Gigaom, © copyright 2014.

Continue reading…

media:content.media:title: Oracle CEO Larry Ellison delivers a keynote address during the 2012 Oracle Open World conference on September 30, 2012 in San Francisco, California. (Photo by Justin Sullivan/Getty Images)

Oracle co-presidents Safra Catz (L) and Mark Hurd talk as Oracle CEO Larry Ellison delivers a keynote address during the 2010 Oracle Open World conference. It was announced today that the pair have been promoted to CEO. (Photo by Justin Sullivan/Getty Images)
Oracle software revenue - chart by RedMonk

item.title: FiveStars raises $26M to build up its digital loyalty program
item.dc:creator: Kevin Fitchard
item.description:
FiveStars has attracted the interest (and funding) of Menlo Ventures as it tries to sell its bare-bones loyalty program into small businesses across the U.S. and Canada.

FiveStars raises $26M to build up its digital loyalty program originally published by Gigaom, © copyright 2014.

Continue reading…

item.title: The critical Shellshock flaw affects many Linux and Apple systems — here’s what you need to know
item.dc:creator: David Meyer
item.description:
Experts are saying the flaw, which affects the bash shell used across many Unix-based systems including Mac OS X and variants of Linux, is more serious than the Heartbleed flaw earlier this year.

The critical Shellshock flaw affects many Linux and Apple systems — here’s what you need to know originally published by Gigaom, © copyright 2014.

Continue reading…

item.title: Ericsson mind melds with Apcera, Talko takes on communications, and what’s up with Watson?
item.dc:creator: Barb Darrow
item.description:
Jason Hoffman, the former Joyent CTO who's now spearheading Ericsson's cloud computing show talks about what he and Apcera are up to. In addition, the Oracle succession saga, Talko talks, and what's up with Watson.

Ericsson mind melds with Apcera, Talko takes on communications, and what’s up with Watson? originally published by Gigaom, © copyright 2014.

Continue reading…

media:content.media:title: Apcera Founder Derek Collison (left) and Ericsson cloud chief Jason Hoffman.

item.title: Yikes: Big Amazon Web Services reboot on the way Friday
item.dc:creator: Barb Darrow
item.description:
Many Amazon Web Services customers will soon be subjected to a reboot of their EC2 instances -- but no one outside of AWS knows why.

Yikes: Big Amazon Web Services reboot on the way Friday originally published by Gigaom, © copyright 2014.

Continue reading…

item.title: Why is “anti-Facebook” network Ello popping up on your social feeds now?
item.dc:creator: Carmel DeAmicis
item.description:
Ello is getting its moment in the spotlight after Facebook alienated a large swath of its LGBTQ user base.

Why is “anti-Facebook” network Ello popping up on your social feeds now? originally published by Gigaom, © copyright 2014.

Continue reading…

item.title: Gigaom Research webinar: Agility and programmability of SDN-powered distributed networking
item.dc:creator: Gigaom
item.description:
In this webinar, our panel will discuss the real-world benefits and business value of SDN-powered converged distributed infrastructure for the enterprise. Join Gigaom Research and our sponsor Pluribus Networks on September 25.

Gigaom Research webinar: Agility and programmability of SDN-powered distributed networking originally published by Gigaom, © copyright 2014.

Continue reading…

item.title: Amazon is reportedly expanding its hardware division to work on smart home devices
item.dc:creator: Kif Leswing
item.description:
Amazon's California-based hardware division is staffing up and working on connected devices for the home as well as a piece of wearable technology.

Amazon is reportedly expanding its hardware division to work on smart home devices originally published by Gigaom, © copyright 2014.

Continue reading…

item.title: Twitter’s proposed polling feature isn’t much help for brands
item.dc:creator: Carmel DeAmicis
item.description:
Brands might not like Twitter's new embedded polling feature if it rolls out to the public.

Twitter’s proposed polling feature isn’t much help for brands originally published by Gigaom, © copyright 2014.

Continue reading…

item.title: Comcast comes out swinging in defense of merger, blasts Netflix and Discovery
item.dc:creator: Jeff John Roberts
item.description:
Comcast's top lawyer is taking a more aggressive tone at a time when attention is shifting to the internet implications of its proposed merger with Time Warner Cable.

Comcast comes out swinging in defense of merger, blasts Netflix and Discovery originally published by Gigaom, © copyright 2014.

Continue reading…

item.title: Need a better flash for your iPhone camera? iBlazr will brighten your day (and night)
item.dc:creator: Kevin C. Tofel
item.description:
Is the puny iPhone flash not quite enough for your stills or video capture? Check out iBlazr, a $50 attachment that plugs into your phone's headphone jack and adds 4 bright LEDs for your photos; it can even sync with the iPhone's native flash.

Need a better flash for your iPhone camera? iBlazr will brighten your day (and night) originally published by Gigaom, © copyright 2014.

Continue reading…

item.title: Twitter open sourced a recommendation algorithm for massive datasets
item.dc:creator: Derrick Harris
item.description:
Twitter recently open sourced an algorithm designed to ease the process of running recommendation engines at large scale. Called DIMSUM, the algorithm pre-processes pairs of possible matches so the other algorithms in the process don't waste resources on poor choices.

Twitter open sourced a recommendation algorithm for massive datasets originally published by Gigaom, © copyright 2014.

Continue reading…

media:content.media:title: A graph showing performance improvements for ad-matching since switching to DIMSUM. Source: Twitter

item.title: Skyhook plays the beacon game, building context into its Wi-Fi geo-location platform
item.dc:creator: Kevin Fitchard
item.description:
There's a lot Skyhook can tell about you based on the Wi-Fi networks you cross everyday. It's putting that info to work with a more refined set of geofencing and profiling tools for advertisers and developers.

Skyhook plays the beacon game, building context into its Wi-Fi geo-location platform originally published by Gigaom, © copyright 2014.

Continue reading…

item.title: The latest anonymous chatting app is both harrowing and intriguing
item.dc:creator: Carmel DeAmicis
item.description:
Should strangers really be providing emotional support to those in need?

The latest anonymous chatting app is both harrowing and intriguing originally published by Gigaom, © copyright 2014.

Continue reading…

item.title: Apple releases, then pulls, an iOS update that accidentally cut off cell service
item.dc:creator: Kif Leswing
item.description:
Apple has pushed an iOS 8 update to iPhones, and it appears to introduce several major bugs. Cellular service is knocked out for some, and others are reporting issues with Touch ID.

Apple releases, then pulls, an iOS update that accidentally cut off cell service originally published by Gigaom, © copyright 2014.

Continue reading…

item.title: India’s orbiter reaches Mars, making it the 4th nation to visit the planet
item.dc:creator: Signe Brewster
item.description:
The spacecraft will study the planet's atmosphere and surface. It cost only about a tenth of the NASA orbiter that recently reached Mars.

India’s orbiter reaches Mars, making it the 4th nation to visit the planet originally published by Gigaom, © copyright 2014.

Continue reading…

item.title: SolarCity breaks ground on huge solar factory in New York, strikes deal with state
item.dc:creator: Katie Fehrenbacher
item.description:
SolarCity has struck a deal with the state of New York to build Elon Musk's "other" massive factory.

SolarCity breaks ground on huge solar factory in New York, strikes deal with state originally published by Gigaom, © copyright 2014.

Continue reading…

media:content.media:title: A Silevo cell, image courtesy of Silevo.

item.title: France’s Free may use Android TV for its next set-top box
item.dc:creator: Janko Roettgers
item.description:
Android TV devices will be available for sale in the U.S. in the next few months, but in France, they may also come in the form of pay TV set-top boxes.

France’s Free may use Android TV for its next set-top box originally published by Gigaom, © copyright 2014.

Continue reading…

item.title: MemSQL distributes its database across data centers, takes In-Q-Tel investment
item.dc:creator: Derrick Harris
item.description:
MemSQL has secured an investment from intelligence-focused venture capital fund In-Q-Tel, and has released a new version of its database software that includes automatic replication of data across data centers.

MemSQL distributes its database across data centers, takes In-Q-Tel investment originally published by Gigaom, © copyright 2014.

Continue reading…

item.title: Wither Tizen phones? Samsung scales back software engineers in its mobile division
item.dc:creator: Kevin C. Tofel
item.description:
Having worked with Tizen since 2011, Samsung has yet to launch a Tizen-powered phone. Now, the company is moving 500 software engineers away from its mobile division, which suggests a revised Tizen strategy for the Internet of Things and connected consumer electronics.

Wither Tizen phones? Samsung scales back software engineers in its mobile division originally published by Gigaom, © copyright 2014.

Continue reading…

item.title: Apple acquires Prss, a company that builds tools for iPad magazine creation
item.dc:creator: Kif Leswing
item.description:
Apple has purchased Prss, a Dutch company that produced browser-based tools for making iPad magazines. It looks as if the Prss service will be shut down.

Apple acquires Prss, a company that builds tools for iPad magazine creation originally published by Gigaom, © copyright 2014.

Continue reading…

item.title: Upcoming Gigaom event: Emerging trends in IoT standards and the quantified self at Structure Connect
item.dc:creator: Gigaom
item.description:
Find out more about securing standards in IoT and the growing tracker device movement at Structure Connect’s Mapping Sessions this October in San Francisco.

Upcoming Gigaom event: Emerging trends in IoT standards and the quantified self at Structure Connect originally published by Gigaom, © copyright 2014.
